title: Your plan to make LCS exciting doesn't work...
body:
You tried to make games more fast paced and snowbally to make professional play more hype and fun to watch

But all you've done is ruin soloq...

You've seen all the posts about how games are too short and not fun and one sided all the time, and that how they last 20 minutes and everything. It's the complete opposite for competitive play.

The average game time for week 1 was 40 minutes... (http://www.lolesports.com/en_US/articles/na-lcs-week-1-numbers )

Today Game 3 TSM VS TL there were only 2 kills at 35 minutes. If anything the first tower gold doesn't make a difference in pro play because everyone still farms for 30 minutes like it was before.

You've just made soloq a chaos mayhem and it's not fun. Please just take away tower gold or reduce it or what not.

The 4-5 man dive bot meta at level 4 to take tower before the enemy gets back and ~700 gold for one person is just too much.

Your plan didn't work. I don't want to wait until season 8 for you to fix it.

tl;dr
pro games are still 40 mins and soloq is 15 mins and unfun. fix plz

Obviously pro players are there to make money and win titles and prizes. In any competitive sport, that's the #1 thing. I don't see why League should be treated any different. If Riot considers they can make money from a competitive League game, then more power to them.

In other games, watching people be competitive _is_ the entertaining part because they showcase the appeal of the game. In League, part of the game's appeal is that there's all these champs you build all these different ways. Pro play today is the exact opposite of that appeal. The vast majority of the time you see the same handful of champs built the same way over and over again.

I mean damn, you can watch an entire tourney or watch the exact same match ten times in a row and almost not be able to tell the difference. Competitive League was not always like this. If I were Riot, I would be trying to **hide** those cookie cutter pro matches instead of promoting them. Once the outside viewer starts to recognize that "Seen one League match, seen 'em all" is more true than it should be, you've lost a potential source of income.

Actually, viewership has been on the way up.
Worlds this year was the most watched worlds yet.

2011 worlds posted about 1.7 million unique viewers.

The 2012 worlds had about 22 million unique viewers. 11 TIMES THAT OF THE PREVIOUS YEAR.

2013 showed 32 million unique viewers.

2014 showed 27 million. (it is worth noting that this decrease was largely due to timing of the games. They were at very late night hours for North America and Europe due to the hosting location being South Korea, many people watched rebroadcasts but it still caused a viewership drop)

In 2015, unique viewership rose back up to 36 million. (Games were in Europe, better viewing times for the much larger western population)

2016 posted 43 million unique viewers, that is nearly DOUBLE from 4 years ago.


So no, the viewer count has NOT been drastically decreasing.
Whatever Riot is doing for promotion is working, because more people are tuning in every year, barring 2014, which is explained above.

While this is true, I found out personally that giving me 600+ gold for first turret snowballs me hard. I play Ekko mid with TP now just because I want fb turr and mid is the easiest to get. Reset lane, go b and get sheen, tp back while enemy mid just recalled. Use sheen procs together with E taking mid turr down to half hp by the time the enemy returns. By 7-10 mins, I get fb turr. Then 600g gives me more items and I can roam and pick up more kills. So yeah, though not significant in compiled games, in individual games, fb turret gold has helped me snowball a lot easier.
If anything, making things more snowbally made pros play MORE passive, as screwing up will generally cost you the game now, so risk-taking is worse.

The problem with your argument is not the first blood tower gold that is causing this issue. Its a myriad of reasons, the gold itself makes fuck all of a difference. The issue at hand is, once you lose the first tower, the map begins to unravel. This causes you to lose vision control of your own jungle, and with damage being so ridiculous, gaining it back becomes very hard because you get exploded for leaving your safe zone. Not to mention the low quality of vision nowadays, like for instance, if you look back at old lcs games, or tournament games, any come from behind wins, or game turn arounds were done by lighting the map up and avoiding fighting. With the low amount of vision, you are bound to walk into somebody, or find yourself in an awkward position eventually. The changes over the last couple seasons were all a factor to this. Reducing vision to make supports not feel like walking ward bots, even though they are essentially the only class that buys sightstone in random pub games, and they are only limited to 3 wards and 1 pink, which in essence is little to no vision, and you constantly need to recall to refill the charges. Adding keystones, and pumping masteries with just outright flat damage increases across the board was another factor, and then now with most assassins being too high risk for a much lower reward, and having adcs not being necessary for tower killing anymore, and the games ending before they can take over the games, just snowballed into what we have now. 


The way to combat this begins with towers, and making them have higher resistances, and either more damage, or more AS, and have the towers past tier 1 be stronger and stronger as you take them down. there is not logical reason for nexus towers to be the same strength as tier 1 towers, the next step is re-evaluate vision. Why do i need an item slot for a pink ward? or a ward in general for that matter. Their trinket system was not what people wanted, however the first iteration was completely fine, and essentially similar to what people wanted. Both yellow upgrades was the most balanced thing the game ever had for vision, and they went and shit all over that for no reason. Nobody bought blue trinket, so they thought, better overhaul the whole thing instead of fixing that one trinket to do something else. The third step, is to lower damage, and retool how keystones and masteries work in general. Masteries should not be your go to damage tools. They should be a choice between a handful of things, and they should not be an extra passive ability. they should just be passive stat games, and should not have any kind just extra damage added to them. I don't have a problem with damage increases, like the 5% for 2.5% even though that is kind of a silly trade off, it should not be, your abilities deal more damage on top of what they say in the tooltip. Things like deathfire touch are almost like hidden power, a thing they were quite against at one point.
